  [0mAll: before reading further, make sure you're up on the site guidelines and don't post political or
  [0mideological flames to this thread. If you're hot under the collar, please cool down and wait for your
  [0mcuriosity to come back before commenting (and maybe even reading) further. This is a good test case to see if
  [0mHN can stick to its intended spirit: [34mnews.ycombinator.com/newsguidelines.html[0m
  [0m
  [0mEdit: There are now multiple pages of comments in this thread. If you want to see the later pages, click
  [0m'More' at the bottom of the earlier pages. Or get there like this:

  [0m
  [0mAs many have pointed out, a dozen or so submissions on this topic were flagged by users. That's actually the
  [0mimmune system working as intended, but another component of the system is that moderators rescue the very most
  [0mhistoric stories so HN can have a single big thread about them. We did that 4 years ago, also for Brexit,
  [0metc.
  [0m
  [0mSince this was the first submission on the topic, it seems fairest to be the one to restore. (It's still on
  [0mour todo list to have some form of karma sharing for situations like this, to make it be less of a race and/or
  [0mlottery.)
  [0m
  [0mI changed the URL from [34mwww.cnn.com/[0m since that is not the most useful link and the AP seems as close as one
  [0mcan get to a neutral source.
  [2m‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ[0m

  [1mdorkwood[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0m¬º There's a famous optical illusion ¬Ω with a spinning silhouette of a dancer. When you ¬æ, look at it, you'll
  [0mswear it's spinning in one direction ‚Äî say, counter-clockwise. In fact, you'll be so sure it's spinning
  [0mcounter-clockwise, that the idea it could be spinning in the opposite direction will seem impossible to you.
  [0mBut if you stare at it long enough, and intently enough, you can make it spin the other way.
  [0m
  [0mI've noticed the same phenomenon with political views.
  [0m
  [0mPeople on the left think that anyone on the right is a lunatic, and everyone on the right thinks the same
  [0mthing about the left. I, as most people do, lean in one direction politically, so naturally any comment I see
  [0mcoming from my side seems reasonable to me. In fact, it seems impossible that a reasonable person could think
  [0many other way. But since I grew up in a family that leaned in the opposite direction, and I shared their same
  [0mmindset in my younger days, I can now draw on that experience, and I can take a political tweet that everyone
  [0mon my side thinks is insane, and I can stare at it, and just as with the spinning dancer, I can flip it in my
  [0mhead so it seems reasonable.
  [0m
  [0mTo me, it's a testament to the power of the tribal instincts within us. We think it's the other side that's
  [0mcrazy, but we're all under the same spell. ‚Öô

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mBelieving in the institutions of family (and monogamy as a commitment to that institution), the objective‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mrule of law, moral obligation through duty of various kinds of community service, prudence, faith as an‚Å£

    [1mprobably_wrong[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mit's just as important that we start with a foundation of agreed upon facts. In other words, reality isn't[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3ma point of view.[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mI don't think these two things are as strongly related as you suggest. Two reasonable people can look at the‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0msame problem with the same facts, make reasonable guesses on what the best course is, and yet reach two‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcompletely different, [3mreasonable[0m approaches to the problem. Otherwise, we would have already decided which‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mprogramming language is the best one.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mSome situations are more clear cut than others, and I agree that we need to separate facts from opinion‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mbetter. But for situations as complex as the present and future of a country there might very well not be a‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m"right" way.‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mparticular recommended at a personal level but not especially useful in politics. The critical tool is the‚Å£

     [1mtempestn[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mCanada feels closer to what your parent described than to what I see in the US, for one. There are of‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mcourse those at the extremes who are very partisan. Although most of those identify more with US politics‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mthan Canadian it seems. But for the vast majority it's much less of an issue than it is in the US. For one‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mthing, most people are not members of one of our federal political parties. Local politicians don't even‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0malign with federal parties, nor do provincial ones in all cases. Many people will shift their vote between‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mideologically similar parties, especially the Liberals and NDP.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mBasically, for myself and most people I know, we vote for the party whose platform most closely matches our‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mown priorities and beliefs, but it's not part of our identities in the same way. The parties themselves are‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0malso far less polarized than in the US. And because it's a multi-party system, you can have minority‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mgovernment that actually functions by garnering support of opposition parties. (We also effectively don't‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mhave multiple veto points though, so generally the governing party is able to govern; I think that also‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mhelps keep things from getting overheated.) Of course, the system isn't perfect. For instance by virtue of‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mbeing both multi-party and first past the post, the winning party usually has the vote of a minority of the‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mpopulation, and still generally holds a majority of seats in parliament. But I've really come to‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mappreciate it in comparison over the past few years.‚Å£
  ‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthe cost. There is rarely an objective 'backed by the science' answer across the board.‚Å£

    [1mhackinthebochs[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mthere is not one single tribe that is objectively correct when it comes to matter of policy when, in fact,[0m‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mfactions. It is not simply a matter of we're right and they're wrong when it comes to settling these‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mborne by those who do not have the means to go for weeks or months without work or cannot work from home.‚Å£

   [1mprossercj[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mIs this not a function of how rationality actually works? We all begin with premises which are fundamentally‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0munproven and unprovable. Our conclusions follow from those premises. Change the premises and the result‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mchanges, though both sets of deductions may be perfectly rational. In other words, rationality is a process,‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mnot a set of conclusions.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mOne word for this is "tradition". If I've piqued your interest, please read Alasdair MacIntyre's book "After‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mVirtue," and also it's sequel with a more provocative title, "Whose Justice? Which Rationality?"‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe two parties provide the opposing agendas which dominate, and the particular characteristics of each‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcandidate are secondary.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mEspecially when neither party has much to offer the average citizen any more, they have built their strength‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mtraditionally on low voter turnout where extreme factions loudly broadcasting gradually become‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mover-represented in the most polarizing way.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mAs cycles continue only the most polarizing issues drive the turnout, and for turnout to grow beyond a‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcertain point the majority of the potential voters must perceive the other party as a more serious threat,‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mwhen compared to any security offered by their own party which they (might) have chosen because they found it‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mless offensive (maybe only in past cycles too).‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe parties no longer need to have as much to offer the average citizen as cycles go on, when they can get‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcontending turnout from their own extremists combined with orders of magnitude more sympathizers who can be‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mconvinced to strongly fear what the _other side_ could take away.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mSeems like after a party has been around for longer than any living person, they will not get support by‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mhaving more to offer average citizens than in previous cycles, only by taking less away from them.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mSo the average citizen hasn't had a positive outcome within reach for a while.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mNow it's too late, these top candidates are realistically as youthful as you can get compared to the grand‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mold parties themselves, and regardless of personal integrity or leadership style can not offer anything above‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mthat from the parties alone.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mEven in the case of Trump's extreme personality, which the Democrats did not even try to nominate a candidate‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mhaving that feature, so this element was as one-sided as you can get.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mI saw agreement from both sides that a wet dishrag could defeat Trump if only 270 electors represent voters‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mwho just plain dislike or hate him. Conversely it was recognized Trump would win if he had merely 270‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0melectors of voters who dislike or hate one or more of the current items on the Democratic party platform.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mNeither strategy can offer anything to the majority of the citizens in the political middle, the true average‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcitizen, since turnout has been driven by fear not opportunity.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mBuilding a coalition from a carefully-crafted extreme attention-getting position, and pushing hard from there‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mso the other side ends up below the 50 percent needed to be in power, has turned out to prevail over‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mrepresenting even the middle 50 percent of voters which is how it was supposed to be at a minimum.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mSo once the issues and/or personalities representing them have reached full polarity, 50 becomes more of a‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mconstant to be converged upon from afar rather than a starting point to build a majority from in both‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mdirections.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mResulting in half the voters who turn out, and half the politically centrist citizens (which is a much larger‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mgroup by a variable multiple of active voters) who will always be dissatisfied and these are two different‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mgroups (but having significant overlap), the latter of which is the core of the majority that all parties are‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0msupposed to be treating as constituents.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mBut the core of the majority in the middle doesn't have a voice because they don't have any party which‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mrepresents them any more, the parties are doing other things with the money and the concerns of centrist‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcitizens are given lowest priority.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe party gets more votes over the long run by fear-mongering against the other side regardless of who the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcandidates are at the time, and only declining resources can be justified which might actually benefit the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mmajority of citizens.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mProblem is, the majority are voting against their own best interest because their own best interest has not‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mbeen available for a number of cycles. Rather each side votes against what's perveived as the other's best‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0minterest instead, since that's the only thing at stake anyway.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mSo the majority of voters end up speaking for the entire population as designed, but all votes are cast‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0magainst someone's best interest because the minority party is voting exactly the same as the majority in this‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mregard.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mSo it's unanimous by both parties that as few of the average citizens as possible should have their best‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0minterest be served, and to redefine democracy in that direction can not be accomplished during a single cycle‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mor maybe not even a single generation.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mEnding up with the choice between a trustworthy Joe and a dishonest Don the thing that doesn't really matter‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mto half the voters as much as it should.‚Å£

  [1mablekh[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mOK, so the transition from Make America Great Again slogan to Make America Decent Again (and Better) reality
  [0mis inevitable and welcome. It is easy to get overjoyed by results of the U.S. Presidential Election (and some
  [0mcelebration certainly is in order).
  [0m
  [0mUniting the country is definitely a commendable goal, though it is easier said than done. The election results
  [0macross all levels clearly illustrate just how divided and polarized this land is. Thus, it will take quite a
  [0mlot of time and effort to see a reasonable progress on this front. We all can play our part in it by a polite
  [0mand constructive dialog with opponents and first finding common ground on such pressing and all-encompassing
  [0missues as coronavirus pandemic, environmental protection, social justice and health care reform.
  [0m
  [0mIn the meantime, let us not forget that, in order to restore the heavily damaged moral fabric of this country,
  [0mrelevant measures should pass through the Congress. And while Democrats retain control of the House, the
  [0mopposing party might retain control of the Senate. Which most certainly will lead to a significant gridlock in
  [0mmoving forward with the democratic and, in some cases, progressive agenda unless Democrats retake control in
  [0mthe Senate. Remember, [3mwinning a battle is not a guarantee for winning a war[0m. That is why the U.S. Senate
  [0mrun-off elections in Georgia to be held on January 5 ([34mgeorgia.gov/vote-2020-runoff-elections[0m) are crucial.

     [1mXorNot[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mHi, I'm from Australia. Voting is mandatory here! Turn out in our elections is 99.x%. You are not obligated‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mto make a choice, but you are obligated under pain of a $30 fine to be registered at a polling station on‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0melection day. You can avoid the fine if you present a valid reason for not voting after the election when‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mnotified. Such a reason would definitely include "I was prevented from voting" or "I was threatened if I‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mvoted", and would be registered with the AEC and investigated seriously.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mOur Electoral commission is the most trusted government body in the country, and has maintained a culture‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mof independence and accuracy. We don't have any form of electronic voting, but generally have election‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mresults on election night.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mOur system has multiple viable political parties! Factions on both the left and right of the spectrum at‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mmultiple government levels have successfully won and lost seats over the years depending on their ability‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mto poll within the electorate. This [3mhas not[0m resulted in them being regarded as "spoilers" to the main‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mpolitical parties, and has acted at times as an effective check on government policy since it encouraged‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mcross-party negotiation through multiple avenues.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mIs our system perfect? No - no system is. But come election night, our representative government [3mactually[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mrepresents the people. If you got 51% of the vote, then 51% of the population, through some means, selected‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0myou as a preferred candidate.‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mGeneral's warning on cigarettes.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m2. Mandate non-partisan districting boards and do away with "safe" districts.‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThis would lose majority-minority districts, which are responsible for a big proportion of our Reps of‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthe mainstream‚Äîthink Steve King for example. And actually they oftentimes have to become radical in order to‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0msurvive primaries. There's only so much you can do here with the current system but, a little would help a‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mlot.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m3. Empower state and local governments by repealing balanced budget amendments and term limits.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mState governments have really hamstrung themselves with these policies, and as a result the federal‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0myou how to live your life. If the federal government has secured rights for all and managed federal‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0manother.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m4. Make voting compulsory, make Election Day a holiday, expand early voting, establish same day registration‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0meverywhere.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThe majority of Senators (and in midterms, the majority of Reps) are elected by a minority of people who are‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mmuch more partisan than the mean. This pushes politicians out of the mainstream.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m5. Federally finance elections, shorten the length, and amend the Constitution to obviate [3mCitizens United[0m.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mCampaigns and their ads are super polarizing. Special interests run messaging campaigns on wedge issues‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m(abortion, immigration, gun rights) in order to pass bills like SOPA or subsidies for fossil fuel energy‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcompanies in the night. Campaign finance reform disarms all this.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m6. Limit the terms of Supreme Court Justices to 18 years and enact jurisdiction stripping.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThe stakes of Supreme Court nominations are so high that it drives us all crazy. We should limit their terms‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mso that 2-term presidents get to nominate 2 Justices, and we should limit the power of the Supreme Court on‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthe basis that it's a deeply undemocratic and unaccountable institution. Pro-lifers feel this every day, as‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mdo progressives. We all agree it's bad; let's change it.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m7. Enact affirmative action for mortgage companies, fund housing assistance, and reform public schools.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThe US has a huge de facto segregation issue due to generations of discriminatory practices by mortgage‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcompanies, and the sky high cost of housing in neighborhoods with good schools. This creates fertile ground‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mfor bubbles and othering, not just in adults but also in children.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m8. Re-establish affirmative action for colleges, and make it free.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThe partisanship gap in the US now largely traces the education and income gap.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mindividual rights. We need to give people the ability to live out their beliefs, but also establish a‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mpluralistic society free of discrimination towards _and from_ the religious. Fighting a culture via‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mfabric is [3m"a metaphor for the flexible but still assured structure of virtue that forms the basis of[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[3mintegrity and holds society together"[0m.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[3mground) that most people in a particular society agree on and recognize as guidelines throughout their daily[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[3mlives[0m. These principles form a cohesive environment of values, which is referred to a moral fabric.‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mI have tried to do the same, signing up for the Flip Side newsletter, among other things. I think it‚Äôs still‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mhard for me, an over-educated progressive, to understand the American right. Here are the problems:‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m1. Reality is often only reported in ‚Äúliberal‚Äù news sources. A lot of information is censored on right wing‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0msources.‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m2. Both types of news sources editorialize in the headline. Sometimes it‚Äôs hard to know they even refer to‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthe same story.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthe Mueller report is not a ‚Äúleft wing‚Äù document and balance is not achieved by putting Mueller against a‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mDouthat write for the New York Times. There‚Äôs no equivalent among the Wall St Journal columnists or Fox News‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mhosts.‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m5. News stories found only in right wing sources are usually mendacious. For example, reporting about the‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mMichigan ballot glitch without mentioning that it was human error and corrected before reporting the‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mresults.‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mconfirms our world view. I can read dozens of articles written from the point of view that universal health‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcare will destroy the country and not one will ever resonate with me. It‚Äôs just too silly to me.‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mYes. Probably the worst thing about this election for me is that it seems to demonstrate conclusively that‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Äúdrain the swamp‚Äù. This distorted world view of us-vs-them tribalism seems to have totally consumed our‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mpolitical system. Objective reality is dismissed by the majority of the population‚Äîmost blatantly on the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mright, but also, increasingly, on the left. Even more shocking to me, highly regarded election data‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mscientists have twice now somehow been blinded to this, releasing poll after poll that fail to capture what‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mis actually happening in the minds of the electorate.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mCarl Sagan, in his 1995 book ‚ÄòThe Demon-Haunted World‚Äô, wrote:‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mI have a foreboding of an America in my children‚Äôs or grandchildren‚Äôs time ‚Äî when the United States is a[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mservice and information economy; when nearly all the key manufacturing industries have slipped away to[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mother countries; when awesome technological powers are in the hands of a very few, and no one representing[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mthe public interest can even grasp the issues; when the people have lost the ability to set their own[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3magendas or knowledgeably question those in authority; when, clutching our crystals and nervously consulting[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mour horoscopes, our critical faculties in decline, unable to distinguish between what feels good and what‚Äô[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3ms true, we slide, almost without noticing, back into superstition and darkness.[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe moment he prophesied now appears to be upon us. I don‚Äôt know how we can restore this country to one where‚Å£

  [1msoftwaredoug[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mOn the data nerd side I continue to be shocked at how people misinterpret the certainty of polls/forecasts.
  [0mForecasts give us probability distributions based on historical polling error data. Not infallible predictions
  [0mthe expected value will 100% happen.
  [0m
  [0mIt‚Äôs fairly revealing of society‚Äôs general innumeracy, just as it was 4 years ago when Trump won.

                                                   [1m‚ñ∂ 75 replies[0m                                                 ‚Äå
                                                   [1;2m‚ñº 75 replies[0m                                                 ‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mpopulation that matters in an election. I‚Äôd expect something like this from junior engineers looking at‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mmetrics for the first time, but these are supposedly the most respective organizations in their field that‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mhave failed spectacularly for the second presidential election in a row. What value do they possibly serve?‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mpostmortem on what went wrong and how it happened again that it deserves.‚Å£

    [1mevgen[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mI really have no idea where this idea that the polls failed comes from. There were only two bad calls this‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcycle and every other outcome was within the margin of error. It was pretty much the same case in 2016 where‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mpeople who had no idea what they were talking about suddenly decided they were certain polling failed‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mbecause they are unable to grasp the concept of margin of error and sample size.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mPolls can only guess about turnout and the try to work backwards from there. The turnout estimates were‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mwrong but not shockingly so, and as a consequence a lot of polls ended up having the result be at the far‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mend of their margin of error. Nothing went wrong. Polling is hard. Get over this idea that you can have some‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0msort of certainty regarding an election until we actually hold the election.‚Å£

     [1mKZeillmann[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mMy issue with polling is that many races were well beyond the margin of error. The Senate polling in‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mparticular was bad this year.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mSara Gideon was favored to win the Maine race in the polling, because there hadn't been a single poll‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mshowing Collins in the lead since July. She lost her race by 9 points.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mIt's also strange to see the region makes a difference in the poll error. The polls in Minnesota were‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mbasically spot-on, but in Wisconsin (demographically very similar), the polling average was Biden +8, with‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mone ABC news poll showing him +17, the kind of outlier result you'd expect with a +8 average. He's gonna‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mwin there by ~1 percentage point.‚Å£

    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mgetting a random sample of voters. Many polls are still married to live interviews and also to landline‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mcontact, and also tied to live interview polling - I think there is a partisan slant that they are not‚Å£

     [1mtitzer[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mSlapping +/- 5% on top of a prediction that is systematically off by ~5% isn't "in the margin of error",‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mit's just simply [3moff[0m. For one prediction, two predictions, no problem. They fall somewhere in this range‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mwith probability distribution (usually a Bell curve around the mean). But for hundreds, if not thousands,‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mof polls to be so [3msystematically[0m off, it is not "within the margin of error" or a statistical fluke. If it‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mwas, you would expect a normal distribution around the mean of the polls. The mean was completely off.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mPut simply, it was sampling bias. Pollsters screwed up. They either sampled the wrong voters, the wrong‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mareas, mispredicted who would turn out, or voters did not accurately report who they planned to vote for.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mGarbage in, garbage out.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mYou can try to correct for sampling bias, but if you are blind to it, as your comment pushes more people to‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mbe, then you will fail.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
     [1mjs2[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£

    [0m[32m‚ñé[0merror in the same direction. Did a single poll that was wrong predict at GOP win and end up a Democratic‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mwin?‚Å£

    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mI wish pollsters would move towards very very large digital samples. You can't get a 15 minute survey but‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mhead-to-head you can get a huge sample for not a lot of money. And don't try to weight it to what you THINK‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mthe turnout will be. Break out likely voter or not. Do not add any inference or opinion or 'math'‚Å£

    [1mdrdec[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThe campaigns do not rely on the publicly available poll data for the reasons you pointed out - they need‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0maccurate polling in order to make serious decisions about resources. They pay polling companies to get‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0maccurate polls and they keep this data private.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThe publicly available polls are done for free by polling companies or by news organizations. Unfortunately‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0msome of these companies apparently have an agenda to push. So they skew their sample away from what the‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mlikely voters are to get the result they want for propaganda purposes.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mI think that the rise of Nate Silver has ironically made this situation worse. He advocates taking an‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0maverage of polls to get a true view of the situation. So if you are skewing you poll to get a certain‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0moutcome and you know the poll will be averaged, you need to warp your results even further.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mOk, disclaimer time - I don't have any inside knowledge or real evidence of any of the above. It does seem‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mto fit however. I can't explain why it seems all the distorting is to make the Dems lead seem bigger than it‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mis - that is, why aren't there pollers on the other side of the aisle doing the same thing?‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mSo you'll have to decide for yourself if there is any merit to the above theory.‚Å£

    [1mpessimizer[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mPolls are astrological race science, and the reason you'll never be able to convince anyone of this is‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0madequately covered by the book [3mWhen Prophecy Fails[0m. I've come to think that their bias is only slightly‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mideological, but instead springs more from a self-serving impulse to mirror the current beliefs of the‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0maudience most likely to believe in polls i.e. people overly impressed by credentials. They enjoy the sheer‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mvolume of numbers, rather than their actual usefulness.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mAlternate phrasings of identical questions asked in polls creates differences in outcome vastly larger than‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthe effects they claim to detect. Somehow Nate Silver managed to get rich by selling synthetic CDOs of‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0marbitrary polls (to people with his identical political outlook.)‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThe only real poll is to ask the same questions, in the same way, as the ballot sheet does. Ideally these‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mshould be asked as people are entering or leaving the voting booth, and people should be paid for their‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mresponses, in order not to bias yourself towards bored loudmouths with nothing to do. This would be good for‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0maccuracy, not for usefulness in anything but generating a suspicion of election fraud.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mInstead, they're trying to figure out what percentage of black people go to the polls in Missouri, and‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mpretending that the self-selected black voter has more in common politically with the general black phone‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0manswerer than the Missouri voter. Relying on that arbitrary assumption is the entire basis of their field.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£

   [1mwill4274[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mI'm on the nerd side too, but I was quite surprised. Sampling isn't the only source of error in election‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mpolling - people also change their minds. In this election, people decided who they were going to vote for‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mhistorically early - the lowest portion of people in the history of exit polls indicated they decided in the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mweek before the election. In theory, this effect should reduce the width of the probability distribution, and‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0myet, the polls were off again, in the same direction as they are always off, by a little bit more than‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0maverage.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mA little scrutiny here is worthwhile. In 2016, for example, the polls were off in part because pollsters‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mweighted the black demographic in proportion to their voting behavior in 2008 and 2012 (when a black‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcandidate was running, boosting turnout). The actual 2016 black turnout looked more similar to 2004 or 2000 -‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mother elections where a black candidate wasn't running. Though I haven't dived into the 2020 polling data,‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mit wouldn't surprise me if a similar effect were at play.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mIt's also become noticeable harder to do polling. Once upon a time, everybody had a landline, so random‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mdialing worked really well. Now, some people have more phones than others, and people are increasingly less‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mwilling to talk to pollsters, increasing the error rate.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThese are all important things to talk about - when you dismiss it as "oh yeah, polls are never perfect," you‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mprematurely shut down the conversation. Don't let perfect be the enemy of the good. The polls could be better‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mand it's important to talk about how.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
    [1msaalweachter[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThere is also "what polls directly measure" and "what we infer from them".‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mBesides the usual adjustments for likely voter models, we also do things like infer how people will vote in‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mHouse and Senate elections based on Presidential polling, because we do a lot more Presidential polling than‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mdown ballot, because money.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mSo one early thing that seems to have happened this year (and again, we are still early in the process to be‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mmaking final verdicts in "what happened" retrospectives) is that people split their ballot more than‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0manticipated, which means that the inferences we were making about down ballot races based on Presidential‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mperformance were off.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mSo not quite a polling error, but an example of uncertainty that may not have been correctly taken into‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0maccount in forecasting.‚Å£
  ‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mYou're picking the easiest number to misread - the overall "chance of being elected", which doesn't really‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mmean anything.‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mare polls that give a particular result with a +- confidence interval. If the polls were to any extent‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcompetently done, you expect the result to be well within that margin of error.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£

   [1mphlakaton[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mI think it's more fundamental than numeracy. If the polls suggest there is a ‚Öî probability you are going to‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mwin an election, but you lose, does that mean the polls were wrong? What if the probability was 9/10?‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mI think the problem is trying to make sense of outliers and uncertainty, and that, in an election with 150M+‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mvariables, you will end up with a result that isn't quite what anyone predicted. In other words: it's not‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mnumeracy, it's epistemology.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
    [1msrtjstjsj[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mFivethirtyeight's polling averaging model underestimated Trump in [3mall[0m the swing states. Trump wine 2-3‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mstates predicted for Biden, and 0 vice versa. States that Biden had a supposedly strong lead in turned out‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mto be statistical ties in the official vote. The direction bias in the polls (about 20 of 25) is obvious,‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mit's not symmetric random error.‚Å£

     [1mTheCoelacanth[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mModeling correlated polling errors is basically what 538's models are all about. They model how far off the‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mpolls could end up being from the actual result based on past elections.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mThe polls are never 100% accurate. The pollsters have to estimate how many of each type of voter will‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mactually show up to vote and what the response rate for each type of voter was. It is not an exact science.‚Å£
  ‚Å£

   [1mwesnerm2[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mTo be fair, we still don't know the loss of votes through mail-in voting. Mail-in voting is more convenient‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mwhich would likely increase participation, but missing signatures, naked ballots, late or undelivered mail,‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0metc can prevent those ballots from being counted.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mWhen there is a major difference in voting patterns between the two political parties, then polls may not‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mactually be inaccurate. In this case, Democrats chose mail-in voting and Republicans, by and large, chose‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0min-person after being directed by the president.‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0minterference through reduced post office efficiency‚Äîin particular, fewer mail sorting machines, lower hours,‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mdeprioritized mails, etc.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mIn short, the polls don't take into account election interference in the post office or unsuccessful‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mdelivery. If most people from both parties were voting in-person, maybe we might have had more parity between‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mthe polls and election results.‚Å£

   [1mbendmorris[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mForecasts give us probability distributions based on historical polling error data.[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThey would give you a probability distribution if they were truly random samples. But in reality, response‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mrates are very low, and pollsters make up for this using demographic weighting and modeling - so the results‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mdon't actually represent any real population, but rather are extrapolated from people who respond onto a‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mhypothetical population that the pollster thinks is likely to vote. This is why they are spectacularly and‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0msystematically off, more and more over time. It's not just variance.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
   [1meinpoklum[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mForecasts give us probability distributions based on historical polling error data.[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Ä¶ and a lot of assumptions about the supposed underlying probability spaces.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
   [1mmeroes[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mYou could also fit the same data with "people polled thought they could vote until their vote was‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m(I do not know why the forecasts are wrong, but I don't see why Parent is at all justified in his statement).‚Å£

    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mThat leaves a challenge: how do you decide what‚Äôs a fact? For example on the vote count. Most outlets say[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mthe reported figures are fact, but it implies trusting the process of counting and reporting. Removing[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mthat implied trust means others can take ‚Äòthere is fraud!‚Äô as fact just as well.[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mTwitter seems to use the mainstream media (eg AP predicting the election outcome) as a base of trust (and[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mso do I). But I‚Äôve come to realize that once you don‚Äôt trust the media, it is easy to believe in another[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mset of facts (that are true for you), and suddenly (to you) it seems Twitter is censoring.[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mI'm glad you brought up the case of the election. It is a harder question for social media to arbitrate‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mcentrally. For example, "There is Fraud" could be true or false, and certainly [3msomewhere you'll find fraud[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mmaking the statement both true in fact and false in spirit. Then, there is the dark matter of [3meverything[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[3mthe newspaper doesnt even cover[0m ‚Äî US newspapers only regularly cover US news, allies, key areas of the‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mworld, and major events. Imagine a dairy-farmer trade war between two asian nations ‚Äî unlikely to be‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mcovered, so what is the truth? For that matter, imagine the civil rights of small minorities in the US ‚Äî‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mdepending on the minority group, unlikely to be covered even by major us newspapers.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mLet me give you a harder example now. Anything to do spanning two sovereign nations, especially one‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0minvolving war, civilian casualties, or war crimes. Pick your example: Russia/Ukraine, China/Taiwan,‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mIndia/Pakistan, Yemen/Saudi Arabia. Both sides will have their national own newspapers which will support‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mtheir own country. Which side does Twitter take?‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThis was accompanied by the removal of quite a few fringe activist and political pages, the most infamous‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mwhich comes to my mind being 'God Emperor Trump', a large meme page that had significant reach during the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m2016 election.‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mpast four years to enforce a bipartisan moderate consensus over their user-bases, restricting any populist,‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mrevolutionary, or potentially dangers speech or users that might produce it.‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mwaxy president who is full of thought and reflection might not be the wise emperor who is still mighty enough‚Å£

  [1mrandomsearch[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0m[This has been hinted at in various threads but I'm stating it clearly here]
  [0m
  [0mA fundamental cause of political polarisation is social media. Tech platforms incentivised by advertising to
  [0mincrease engagement have (probably mostly inadvertently) become manipulation engines that have destabilised
  [0mdemocracies.
  [0m
  [0mI think at this moment in time the tech community should take pause to consider what we have done. We started
  [0mwith heady ideals and hopes, especially for the internet, but we have veered a long way from that vision.
  [0m
  [0mAs engineers, we have great power in this world. For the foreseeable future, our skills will be highly in
  [0mdemand and shape the future of humanity, in every area of society - from finance to health, from entertainment
  [0mto politics.
  [0m
  [0mIf you work for a social media company, or a search engine, or any company that is reliant on adtech or high
  [0mengagement for its income, then I implore you to think long and hard about how your actions may have
  [0mcontributed to bringing us to this point, and whether it is possible to change the course of your organisation
  [0mor it would be better to leave.
  [0m
  [0mMore positively, the large social media networks are now entrenched corporations, and they have lost the
  [0madvantages that startups confer. With sufficient imagination and hard work there are many opportunities to
  [0mdisrupt those companies with the compelling mission of making the world a better, not a worse, place.

                                                   [1m‚ñ∂ 4 replies[0m                                                  ‚Äå
                                                   [1;2m‚ñº 4 replies[0m                                                  ‚Å£

   [1mehsankia[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mI absolutely agree this is an issue, but I honestly think it even transcends social media algorithms. Well,‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mfor one thing, the news media is just as much to blame, pushing clickbait and stories that induce the most‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mrage. The next step is, regardless of social media sites, people tend to share said stories far more, so it's‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0ma vicious circle. I think any large connected social media site, regardless of the algorithms, will lead to‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0ma similar result.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
   [1mThorncorona[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mHint: 'Personalized' algorithms simply mean tailored to one's biases. As in Google will show liberals only‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mliberal articles, and conservatives conservative articles.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
    [1mrandomsearch[0m [35mPP [0m[2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mI think there's an important distinction between recommendation algorithms, which is how I'd describe what‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0myou're referring to, and _algorithms designed to maximise engagement_.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mRecommendation algorithms try to provide content that you'll enjoy, like new movies to watch.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mEngagement algorithms will try to find content that keeps you engaged, even if that means enraging you. They‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mdon't just exploit biases, rather they exploit what triggers you.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
     [1mMahn[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mAnd therein lies the problem, algorithms can't tell if you click and spend time with something because you‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0menjoy it, or because it enraged you.‚Å£

   [1mFooBarBizBazz[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mYeah, there's a lot of really dumb straw-manning going on.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mA good phrase I ran into is "strategic empathy". Like Sun Tzu teaches:‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m"If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles. If you know‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0myourself but not the enemy, for every victory gained you will also suffer a defeat. If you know neither the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0menemy nor yourself, you will succumb in every battle."‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mSadly, humans seem allergic to this kind of thinking. As Orwell writes in "Notes on Nationalism":‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m"The nationalist does not go on the principle of simply ganging up with the strongest side. On the contrary,‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mhaving picked his side, he persuades himself that it is the strongest, and is able to stick to his belief‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0meven when the facts are overwhelmingly against him. Nationalism is power hunger tempered by self-deception.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mEvery nationalist is capable of the most flagrant dishonesty, but he is also ‚Äì since he is conscious of‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mserving something bigger than himself ‚Äì unshakeably certain of being in the right."‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe smart (if mistaken) reasons to vote Trump were always trade and the Democratic Party's abandonment of‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mLabor.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mAnd Republicans, on the other hand, who think Biden is a socialist are delusional.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mIt's possible, though, that people aren't as dumb as they seem. For an individual, pretending not to‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mempathize with the opposition is probably safer in a tribalized society. So perhaps that's what we're really‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mwitnessing.‚Å£
  ‚Å£

     [1mdefen[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mThey haven't been, in the long view. Historically abortion was a Catholic issue, and sometimes liberal‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mProtestant[[31m1[0m]. It generally wasn't an issue for Evangelicals, who were also mainly on the political left.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mThen in the late 60s the teenage son of a popular Evangelical pastor/author[[33m2[0m] became concerned for the‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mrights of the unborn, convinced his father to take that message to the masses, it worked, and Republicans‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mfigured out that it would be a way to build a new coalition.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mIf you look at the extreme countercultures of the 60s, you see one side who hated "the system" that‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mproduced mass affluence, but loved the fruits of it. The other side loved the system, but hated the fruits.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mSo one way to look at it is as a sort of political shibboleth indicating that you were definitely on one‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mside and not the other.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£

    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mMichael Tesler has argued, economic anxiety and discontent among white voters in 2016 appear to be[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mclosely connected to racial resentment. His analysis of survey data indicate that many white voters,[0m‚Å£

    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mimmigrants were taking jobs away from American citizens and reducing wages for American workers.[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mTo sort out these competing explanations, we test the hypothesis that Trump‚Äôs surge among white working[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mclass voters, compared with previous GOP presidential candidates, was due to his explicit appeal to white[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mracial resentment and ethno-nationalism. Thus, Trump‚Äôs campaign may have helped to politicize these[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mattitudes, identifying them with a political party, especially among less educated white voters who tend[0m‚Å£

    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mracial and other issues (Tesler 2016c). To test this hypothesis, we can compare the correlations between[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mscores on the racial resentment scale and relative ratings of the Republican and Democratic presidential[0m‚Å£

    [1mrm445[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mA couple of ideas: (1) Centrism is situational. One might think that the status quo is objectively‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mreasonably close to the ideal, in terms of the general way society is arranged even if there are many‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mimperfections. (2) Centrism is technocratic. If you don't favour a lurch to the left or right, it would make‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0msense to want efficient improvements to how things are run - accepting good ideas regardless of which area‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mof the political compass they come from, bipartisan support for policies on their merits.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mBased on the above, centrism (and indeed, being centre-left or centre-right) seems viable as a real belief‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthat people can hold, not some strategy to appear above it all for social benefit, or as a stratagem used by‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0msomeone actually highly partisan. A centrist's goals could be directly met by encouraging trial of‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mdifferent ideas across the political spectrum, and consistent meta-level rules rather than tribalist‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthinking. Trying to rise above the bunfighting isn't the benefit of centrist views, it's a necessity to‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0menable the things they want to achieve.‚Å£
  ‚Å£

  [2m‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ[0m

  [1mChuckMcM[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mOne of the things this election, and the last four years, has shown me, is the impact of technology on our
  [0mpolitical discourse. It hasn't been a "good" insight.
  [0m
  [0mFederal Election records indicate that the leadership of technology companies overwhelmingly supported a set
  [0mof values that their employees appear to just as overwhelmingly reject. That dissonance is really quite
  [0mremarkable.
  [0m
  [0mI see one of the fundamental challenges facing the new administration is how to address this. I am not a fan
  [0mof government regulation, more of a "let the markets decide" kind of guy. I recognize however there is a
  [0msystemic risk where the technology "owner" can exploit it to harm society in a way that was previously
  [0mimpossible.
  [0m
  [0mWhile the country has focused on disinformation and hate speech, consider a company that controls, in real
  [0mtime, the self-driving software in a car. Such a technology, if weaponized, to could kill hundreds of
  [0mthousands of people. Or it could be weaponize to kill select people who were in the intersection of riding in
  [0ma self-driven car and in disfavor by the company that really controls that car.
  [0m
  [0mEarly on in my career I chose not to work for military contractors who were the "big" employers in Los Angeles
  [0mat the time I graduated from college. They were clearly engaged in finding clever, or at least more effective,
  [0mways to kill people and that wasn't where I wanted to spend my time. But what about someone working on self
  [0mdriving? It saves lives by avoiding some of the things end up resulting in crashes. But it also provides an
  [0mopportunity for great evil.
  [0m
  [0mDo we trust the person in charge to not be evil? Companies change and while they might declare their
  [0mintentions when they are growing, what happens when they are on top? Sometimes those quaint notions get cast
  [0maside when being a little bit evil makes what you're trying to do that much easier or maybe that much more
  [0mprofitable.
  [0m
  [0mWhat is the appropriate response, in a democracy, to a small number of people controlling a potential weapon
  [0mthat can destroy that democracy? Sadly this is no longer an idle question.
  [0m
  [0mI don't have any answers here, just more questions.

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mConsider Facebook, which is a popular bad guy here[[31m1[0m]. There have been "crank" bulletin board systems since‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthe 70's at least, and before that with HAM radio operators riling each other up over various perceived‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mslights and insults. In 2016 we got to see that with a precision advertisement targeting system, and way‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mmore insights into people than ever existed before, companies like Cambridge Analytica could precisely‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mtarget individuals who were susceptible to a particular line of reasoning. CA essentially offered‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mRadicalization As a Service. We are still dealing with that to this day. Was there any reason to worry about‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mBBS software? Not when it was a self selecting group. But when the BBS became a billion BBSes all hosted on‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthe same platform with clear insights into the demographics, fears, and hopes of all of those BBSes at‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0monce, that was something new. And it changed the risk profile and was weaponized against people.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mIt has always been desirable for groups to find somewhat like minded people in order to form a group for‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcollective action. That is the 'demand' side of the question, but before Facebook it wasn't economic to do‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthat at scale. With Facebook it did become economic to do that, and it gave anyone a new capability. Not all‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mof those people have (or had) people's best interest at heart and so we get the bad as well as the good.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mPrior to self driving cars with over the air updates, continuous network connectivity, and full access to‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mall systems on a car, has their been the capability (actualized or not) for someone anywhere in the world to‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mtarget a specific car and take control away from the driver. The previous poster child, for vehicles‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0manyway, were cars with computers that controlled things like engine starting/stopping and brakes. One issue‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mwas that you had to be near the car to know which one you wanted to attack. Self driving cars finesse that‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mby giving you an interior camera view. It is a different realm of problem.‚Å£

   [1mtptacek[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe big difference is that 2000 revolved around a disputed recount, in a race with a margin of fewer than‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m1000 votes. There will be recounts in this race, but:‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m(1) There's no reason to believe they'll change the outcome much (recounts in 2016 didn't) --- states have‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mlearned since 2000 and have moved away from faulty ballot designs.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m(2) The recounts will be occurring in multiple states, and Trump needs to sweep them.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m(3) The margins in those recounts are much bigger than in 2000 --- tens of thousands of votes, not hundreds.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
   [1mjcranmer[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe biggest factor in Florida is that the ballot marking system that Florida used at that time was extremely‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mprone to failure, especially with regards to machine reading of ballots (which itself could cause an apparent‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mmark on the ballot!). This means that trying to divine whether or not a ballot recorded an intent to vote‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mfor a candidate can be subjective and depends on the exact standard you want to use, which Florida didn't‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mspecify (and the Florida Supreme Court ruled was ultimately too vague).‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mSince 2000, most states have switched to optical scan ballots as their paper records. These ballots have much‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mlower error rates, closer to 1 error per million votes. I don't think there's been a single race using‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0moptical scan ballots where a recount actually caused a winner to switch.‚Å£
  ‚Å£

    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[3mthe losing side[0m accepting that loss, action that undermine that are quite problematic.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£

    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mgovernors, and of course the heavily tilted supreme court now), [3mthen[0m things would have gotten dicey. In‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mthat situation, just like in other strong-man democracies, the outcome of the election would have been‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mrigged. Would democrats have backed down? Or would they have disputed the elections, even though formally‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mthey lost them? That's the kind of thing that breaks a democracy; because both backing down and‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mconfrontation are terrible outcomes.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mTo their credit - because that's how it's supposed to work in a democracy - those toss-up states did not‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mseriously try to steal votes (although the vote-segregation thing is pretty close). And of course we don't‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m[3mknow[0m Trump would really have stolen the election, given the opportunity, since it never arose. But we can‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0msee that he took all possible steps in that direction at least; and that's something the US needs to deal‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mwith in the future for the sake of stability. It ended well this time; it might not every time.‚Å£

     [1mthrowaway201103[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mThe constitution declares that the president is elected by the states, not by the people directly. The‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0melectoral college serves to moderate the influence of dense population areas.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mOn a straight popular vote basis, the large urban centers in a handful of states would select the‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mpresident. Their interests and motivations will necessarily be different from rural areas.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mThe electoral college gives populous states proportionally more influence, as they have more congressional‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mrepresentatives and thus more electoral votes. But it serves to balance that against the interests of less‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mpopulated states, which are also part of the country and should not be considered completely irrelevant in‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mthe process.‚Å£

   [1mmshumi[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mIs it fair if people can be restricted from competing in the property markets by people who faced no such‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mrestrictions themselves when acquiring that land capital. Zoning licensing, etc.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe elephant in the room is that for most people the majority of their net worth is tied up in housing‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m(property) and as interest rates drop the nominal value of this property increases way faster than the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mnominal wages of labor. This property can then be used to create information insensitive debt that ignores‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0many notion of liquidity at an artificially higher nominal value. This debt is then used to pay wage-labor who‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mincreasingly cannot acquire property themselves. At the end of the day, only real property is wealth (land,‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mip rights, equity, collectibles, and machinery) and labor is denied the opportunity to earn a larger share of‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mproperty themselves. Any solution is politically difficult.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
    [1mtachyonbeam[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mI agree that there is an issue with housing being so inaccessible to labor. In my city, even with a six‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mfigure salary, it's hard to buy something alone. You increasingly need two six figure plus salaries to make‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mit work. IMO, part of the problem is that everyone views housing as an investment. People trade real estate‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mlike trading cards. We forget that homes have a more fundamental purpose (to house people).‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mIf you can't afford a home, as a way to get your foot in the door, you can buy ETFs on the stock market. You‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcan also buy REITs as a way to invest in real estate. There are even diversified REIT ETFs. It's like being‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0ma landlord, you get paid dividends, but you don't have to lift a finger. If someone has some money on the‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mside but can't yet afford property, this is a relatively safe way to get into investing and the real estate‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mmarket IMO.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThe unfortunate difference though is that mortgage rates are subsidized by the government, interest rates‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mare kept artificially low. If you get a mortgage to buy a property, it's effectively leveraged investing.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mYou pay a small downpayment (as low as 10% nowadays) and you're basically investing with someone else's‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mmoney. You can't do that with REITs. Nobody will lend you 10X your downpayment at 2% interest to buy ETFs.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mIf you can't afford to own property, you are denied this leveraged investing opportunity.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mPersonally, as a condo owner, I would be OK with condo prices not going up. As prices increases, so do my‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mtaxes. I can just invest in the stock market. I don't need my home to be an investment, I just need it to be‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0ma comfortable place to live.‚Å£
  ‚Å£

    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mPeople want to own residential units. Ownership is and should be more expensive than occupancy.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mA residential unit also needs power, sewer, water, schools, fire dept, police dept, parks and recreation,‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0msanitation and other services, transportation, commerce, infrastructure and roads. And staff to run all‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mthis. Building up vertically on a x30 multiplier doesn‚Äôt mean that city can provide all the services and‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0maccess resources to service the multiplier effect of said parcel of land. This is why high density cities‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mend up being unaffordable.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mIf high density cities are built up to accommodate more affordable homes and below market value homes, the‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mresidents effectively pay negative taxes by benefitting more from the city than they pay in as taxes. The‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mmath doesn‚Äôt work out. If it did, we would have more townships with high density as well as‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0maffordability..and cost of living going down. But in my observation,such things never happen. At least from‚Å£

  [1monecommentman[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mThanks for the valiant attempts to keep this discussion from devolving into a full-fledged dumpster fire.
  [0m
  [0m1. The US, by the most generally accepted definition, has had continuous governance as a democracy since 1788.
  [0mJust one more election, and not the most contentious or momentous by a long shot.
  [0m
  [0m2. Current reported spread in votes between D and R are pretty slim, 75.0M v. 70.7M Wikipedia 11PM EST 11/7.
  [0m
  [0m3. Whatever your partisan opinion, at least 70M American adults, 48.5% of those voting, disagree with you and
  [0mthink you‚Äôre an idiot. Try not to confirm the fact with your comments.
  [0m
  [0m4. Challenging the validity of the voting process is a time-honored tradition during tight races. Stop
  [0msounding like newbies. This is the only time that the validity of the electoral process gets enough visibility
  [0mto figure out if anything‚Äôs broke. Seriously broke? See 1.
  [0m
  [0m5. A paper trail is a beautiful thing.
  [0m
  [0m6. And what a wonderfully fertile field these comments are for use as examples of propaganda, inflammatory
  [0mrhetoric and logical fallacies. Wish I was teaching a course right about now. Timely for the application of
  [0mmanure on fields too‚Ä¶
  [0m
  [0m7. It would be nice if the mods kept the discussion away from an r/politics-ization of HN. The sides are
  [0mpretty obvious and enforcing an arbitrary quota of half blue hurrah/half red hurrah would lead to a better
  [0mflow and balance. Heavy-handed, but appropriate in these few cases IMHO.
  [0m
  [0mThe brilliant, stupid, wise, foolish, angry, mellow, old, young, rich, poor, naive, cynical, kind, nasty,
  [0msophisticated, brutish American people have spoken. Whether you agree with the results or not, it‚Äôs a
  [0mbeautiful thing.

  [1mchmod600[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mA voting system needs to be accurate but it also needs to inspire confidence. I think the U.S. failed on the
  [0mlatter point. Let me be clear that I don't think this affected the [3moutcome[0m, only the [3mconfidence in the[0m
  [0m[3moutcome[0m.
  [0m
  [0mMail-in voting has existed for a long time, but it is being done at a larger scale and in new ways and new
  [0mplaces. It was a mistake to do it during such a contentious election. Covid is not a good enough reason: it's
  [0measy enough to drop the ballot in a county box so the secretary of state has a chain of custody for all valid
  [0mballots. I would actually prefer voter ID as well as people standing there to do a brief check. In addition to
  [0mpreventing fraud, it also helps remind voters if they forgot to sign or something.
  [0m
  [0mAlso, I think it needs to be said that a lot of people hate Trump. Hate can cause people to do things that
  [0mthey would never imagine doing otherwise, like election fraud. It doesn't need to be a conspiracy‚Ä¶ just a lot
  [0mof individuals doing small stuff (post office employees throwing away likely Trump ballots, etc.).
  [0m
  [0mAnd it doesn't help that the map looked quite red on the day of the election, and that the poll numbers were
  [0mWAY off, and that the media was rooting for Biden. It all just erodes confidence.

  [1mcharliemil4[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mWe should trust but verify the results. The basis of facts should be settled in the following:
  [0m
  [0m1. Select all ballots that were sent to the same address - or sent to the same Post Office (grouping all PO
  [0mBoxes by post office).
  [0m^ Here you are trying to see if there is systemic voting behaviors out of the ordinary ‚Äî i.e. did 10+ ballots
  [0mgo to one address.
  [0m
  [0m2. Select all ballots that were sent to an alternate address than the voter registration.
  [0m^ This is a general query ‚Äî select a sample set of these and confirm with the registered voter that they did
  [0mindeed receive a mail in ballot.
  [0m
  [0m3. If above is inconclusive, select all registered voters that requested a mail in ballot against the
  [0m2017-2018 Equifax Data to determine if correlations occur.
  [0m
  [0m4. Select all ballots that were the voter did not vote in the last X elections (there are political
  [0mconsultancies that provide information on who NOT to waste your time on because they do not vote), did these
  [0mpeople request a mail in ballot? Were these ballots sent to an alternate address?
  [0m
  [0mFor clarification [[31m1[0m], if one were armed with a SSN or DL and a previous address, one could request a ballot
  [0mon behalf of another person AND have that ballot redirected to a location of their choosing‚Ä¶ including a PO
  [0mBox. The form is included here for reference.
  [0m
  [0m[[31m1[0m] [34mwww.votespa.com/Register-to-Vote/Documents/PADOS_Mai‚Ä¶[0m
  [0m
  [0mEDIT: just so you know, I think both of them did things like this. I want my d%mn democracy back.

  ‚Å£
   [1mdodobirdlord[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mVoting fraud on the scale required to influence a US election is not possible due to voting registration‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mrequirements. Registering any significant amount of fake people is not feasible, and if you are trying to‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcast the votes of any significant number of real people you will quickly have a collision with someone who‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mactually does intend on voting, leading to an investigation and the whole scheme unraveling.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mVoter registration + signature checks + investigating duplicate ballots is a robust system for ensuring that‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0msystematic voting fraud can only achieve a small result without being overwhelmingly likely to be caught. If‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mthe election had actually come down to a margin of a few thousand votes in a single state it might have been‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mworth the resources to do a deep-dive, but with the margins that occurred we can be certain that voting fraud‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mdid not influence the result.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
    [1mblub[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThe claims I've seen were:‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m* dead people "voted" in the election‚Å£

    [0m[32m‚ñé[0msignal. It‚Äôs easy for a state to estimate what percentage of the vote could possibly have been fraudulent,‚Å£

     [1mdodobirdlord[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mI‚Äôll lead off by mentioning that some states already voted by mail and have for many years. So if there‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mwere a problem with this approach that enabled mass voter fraud we would be well aware by now.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mThe ‚Äúblank ballots‚Äù are not blank in the sense that they are interchangeable. Each ballot sent out is the‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mspecific ballot of a specific person. It‚Äôs certainly possible that some ballots were stolen from their‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mintended recipients and mailed back with forged signatures, but what‚Äôs important is whether this could have‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mbeen done on a mass scale to influence the election result. And the answer to that is no. A coordinated‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0meffort to fraudulently return enough ballots to matter would require large-scale raiding of mailboxes to‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0msteal ballots, or stealing ballots in mass quantity soon after they were put into the postal system by each‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mstate‚Äôs election commission. The former is impossible, as it would require an organization comparable in‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0msize to the postal service to be able to go house by house stealing ballots as they were delivered, and it‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mwould be obvious that it was occurring. The latter is easy to detect and trivial to rectify.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mIn both cases, the fraud would be detected as soon as anyone who hadn‚Äôt received their ballot went to their‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mstate‚Äôs election website and requested another ballot and were informed that their ballot had been‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mdelivered and returned.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
     [1mjustin66[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mWhen it comes to fraud, obtaining a ballot is as easy as obtaining a bank check, for example. It's legal‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m(in my state, anyway) for various parties to distribute them, and you could print your own, if you had the‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mright paper. (You'd be in hot water if your ballot wasn't the exact document the state distributes - it's a‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mcrime to distribute a ballot that's prepopulated with the user's data, for example)‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mThe security features of the process do not depend on mail-in ballots being unique or scarce.‚Å£

     [1mdodobirdlord[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mIt is certainly true that the US is frequently behind the curve of other first world nations on government‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mdeployment of new technology. This is largely because of 2 reasons. Reason #1, the US historically is‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mfrequently the first place technologies are deployed on a wide scale, and as a result the US generally has‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mthe earliest and thus the worst version of everything. Reason #2, the US system of federated States‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mintroduces great friction into any system requiring a central authority.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mThe absence of a national voter ID program perfectly exemplifies this. The US has an election system that‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mworks sufficiently well, so there‚Äôs no major impetus to overhaul how voters vote. And the US Federal‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mgovernment doesn‚Äôt even [3mhave[0m a list of all US citizens. In fact, no such list even exists. Moreover, a lack‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mof any existing documentation that a person is a citizen does not necessarily mean that they are not a‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mcitizen due to birthright citizenship or citizenship automatically inherited from parents.‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mConcerns about voter suppression induced by the introduction of a national voter ID are completely‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mlegitimate. The US Federal government lacks the capacity to ensure that every eligible voter is delivered‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0man ID (lacking a list of all citizens), so the burden to acquire one falls on the individual. If this costs‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mmoney, then it constitutes an unconstitutional poll tax. And in any case, since the Federal government is‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mincapable of handling such a responsibility it would fall to the individual states, some of which have‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mdemonstrated historically that they will act to make the process arbitrarily difficult for individuals that‚Å£
    [0m[32m‚ñé[0mthe sitting state legislature would prefer do not vote.‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mrequired, ballots need to have a chain of custody to be valid, and counting is done in a transparent and‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThere's no way to have a safe voting system without trust in the government and how states operate. There's‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mconclusion, usually with very limited information or objective reason to despair. When a situation is‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mupsetting, but not necessarily catastrophic, they still feel like they are in the midst of a crisis.‚Äù‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m([34mwww.psychologytoday.com/us/basics/catastrophizing[0m)‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mWe have experienced ‚Äúgreat damage or suffering‚Äù (i.e., catastrophes), not merely upsetting situations. The‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mmedia hasn't been catastrophizing; they've been reporting about catastrophes.‚Å£
