    [1mhn_throwaway_99[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mMy pet theory is similar, but slightly more nuanced, and comes from my history of being harshly bullied in‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mmiddle school.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThe group dynamics of bullying are pretty straightforward. There will always be bullies at the top who want‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mto cement their status by showing their power as a bully. To get a significant group of people to go along‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mwith the bullying, however, (think everyone laughing along when the bully makes fun of someone) that group‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mneeds to be really unsure of their place in the social hierarchy. They know bullying is wrong but at that‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mpoint are somewhat terrified of ending up on the wrong side of the bullying. That's why you see so much‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mbullying in middle school, where kids are usually just starting to find their place in the social hierarchy.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mI think in the US (and many Western democracies) there is currently so much unease about economics, about‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mfinding a good, and more importantly, stable job, that the situation is ripe for a bully to come along and‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mtake advantage of people's general worries about their place in the world to think "better for me to be a‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mbully myself than to be the person that ends up on the bottom of the totem pole". Think of the crowd‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mlaughing along when Trump mocked a reporter with cerebral palsy.‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mFrom Parade Magazine, September 10, 1989 ‚Äì As I got off the plane, he was waiting for me, holding up a[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3msign with my name on it. I was on my way to a conference of scientists and TV broadcasters, and the[0m‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3msame name as that science guy?"[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mIt took me a moment to understand. Was he pulling my leg? "I am that science guy," I said. He smiled.[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3m"Sorry. That's my problem. I thought it was yours too." He put out his hand. "My name is William F.[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mBuckley." (Well, his name wasn't exactly William F. Buckley, but he did have the name of a contentious TV[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3minterviewer, for which he doubtless took a lot of good-natured ribbing.)[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mAs we settled into the car for the long drive, he told me he was glad I was "that science guy" ‚Äî he had so[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mmany questions to ask about science. Would I mind? And so we got to talking. But not about science. He[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mwanted to discuss UFOs, "channeling" (a way to hear what's on the minds of dead people ‚Äî not much it turns[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mout), crystals, astrology ‚Ä¶ He introduced each subject with real enthusiasm, and each time I had to[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mdisappoint him: "The evidence is crummy," I kept saying. "There's a much simpler explanation." As we drove[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mon through the rain, I could see him getting glummer. I was attacking not just pseudoscience but also a[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mfacet of his inner life.[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mAnd yet there is so much in real science that's equally exciting, more mysterious, a greater intellectual[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mchallenge‚Äîas well as being a lot closer to the truth. Did he know about the molecular building blocks of[0m‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mancestors found in 4-mil-lion-year-old volcanic ash? What about the raising of the Himalayas when India[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mwent crashing into Asia? Or how viruses subvert cells, or the radio search for extraterrestrial[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mintelligence or the ancient civilization of Ebla? Mr. "Buckley" ‚Äî well-spoken, intelligent, curious ‚Äî had[0m‚Å£

  [1mbetwixthewires[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mFor a site full of engineers I'm surprised to see the discussion center on partisan politics, talking points,
  [0munsourced claims and demands for sources, bickering over every detail, when what I'd want to talk about among
  [0mtechnical people is the fact that Biden hasn't actually won, based on the rules of the system. He claimed he
  [0mwon. So did Trump. Neither are backed by anything tangible, yet. It looks like the PA AG has called for a
  [0mstatewide audit of votes, several court orders have been issued in several states, including Michigan and
  [0mWisconsin, there are lawsuits in several jurisdictions, and recounts in Georgia and Nevada are going to start
  [0msoon. Notice how I'm not saying the lawsuits and accusations are founded, because I'd like to talk about the
  [0msystem.
  [0m
  [0mThis is far from over. You could have votes invalidated. This is only over when the electors travel to DC and
  [0m270+ vote for one person. That could be halted. You could see the house delegations vote, you could see state
  [0mor federal courts rule, you could even see some state legislative bodies make decisions on it.
  [0m
  [0mIt takes a lot more than a claim of victory and a news organization calling it for an election to be over, and
  [0mI'd expect a bunch of very smart people to know that.

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3msustainability.[0m‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThe free market will NEVER voluntarily choose compliance costs. The value simply isn't there.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThe free market is an engine to optimise profit. That's it. All other considerations are secondary.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mwage, etc‚Ä¶ my only hope is that I can attract a niche market that will pay a premium for that. But history‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mhas shown us that is simply not the case.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mchain) the rest of the world would have to follow through.‚Å£

   [1m0xB31B1B[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mI kind of entirely disagree with the your read on the situation. The struggles that America has aren't that‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mit doesn't have a common culture, the struggles are that it has too many veto points in its political process‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mso it is extremely difficult for popular majorities to execute on a political vision, and it is extremely‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mdifficult for the population of the country to hold their leaders accountable when the multiple veto points‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mlead to a diffusion of responsibility. The struggle we have is that popular majorities cannot enact their‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mpolicy preferences, and then do not receive electoral feedback based on the policies they enact. America‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mdoesn't need a common culture, it needs a better feedback loop for things to go from idea -> popular will ->‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mpolitical power -> policy change -> impact on the people.‚Å£
  ‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m(bear with me), The problem is that when 'facts' are presented in form of live media (audio, video) the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mchances of it being interpreted as 'reality' by our adaptive brain as reality is high.. because you just saw‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m& heard it, there in very little space there to inject intellectual discretion there, and even if you do you‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mstill have to have a special case for 'that reality'.‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe Constitution of the United States is a document written to preserve co-equal sovereignty of a bunch of‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mstates that wanted to be closer to nations than provinces, while avoiding the then-very-apparent risk of‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcentralized absolute governing authority.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe framers of the Constitution didn't get everything right, but it's very useful to keep that perspective in‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mmind when trying to understand the form of the US government.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mIf you take the perspective of states as sovereign, with federation between them, then the Electoral College‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mstarts to make a lot more sense. The goal was to preserve the power of a [3mstate[0m in the federal government, as‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mmuch as to represent the collection of people from all states - both concepts were critical. The idea is that‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mpeople from the nation deserve representation [3mand[0m that each state (and the people from that state as a‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0msub-population) deserve representation.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mIf federation of states is a core concept of the subdivision of governing responsibility, then it makes sense‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mto build a system that ensures each state has meaningful weight in the governance of that federation.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mNone of this is an argument for or against the Electoral College, nor should it be interpreted as arguing for‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mthe correctness/effectiveness/righteousness/morality of the institution. It is simply an attempt to share‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mperspective to help understand why the system is the way it is.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mAs originally defined, the House of Representatives was the only piece of the federal government intended to‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mdirectly represent the people of the nation. Senators were originally chosen by state legislatures. The‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mSenate was intended to represent the states, not the people directly.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe Electoral College was an intermediary to represent both the states and the people - as a compromise, it‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mhas many failings that seem obvious today. There is no federal mandate as to how a state's electors choose to‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcast their votes. Each state is responsible for regulating its own voting - this includes how people vote‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mand how electors are chosen and how those electors vote. It is mere happenstance that the majority of states‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mhave a winner-takes-all allotment strategy for their electors. Maine and Nebraska notably assign their‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0melectors proportionally.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mIt is also interesting to note that the tie-breaking mechanism for an Electoral College tie devolves to the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mHouse, not with one vote per representative, but with one vote per state. This is another example of the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mconcept that [3mstates[0m are a concept deserving of representation.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
   [1mceilingcorner[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe US is not and was never supposed to be a popular vote democracy. The founding fathers recognized the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mdangers of populism and subsequently made sure that the government is a republic.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
    [1mGwypaas[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mMichael Barbaro: [3mSo this winner-take-all system, this is not something envisioned by the framers. It seems[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[3mlike it kind of came to us in a pretty haphazard way.[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mJesse Wegman: [3mRight. People like to imagine that the system that we used today was handed down to us from[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[3mthe framers. And in fact, the framers didn‚Äôt talk at all about the winner-take-all rule. It didn‚Äôt come up[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[3mat the convention. And when they saw it start to be adopted in the states in the early 1800s, they were[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[3mhorrified. James Madison, the man we think of as the father of the Constitution, tried to pass a[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[3mconstitutional amendment prohibiting the use of winner-take-all rule because he saw how corrosive it was to[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[3merase up to half of voters in the state.[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m[34mwww.nytimes.com/2020/10/22/podcasts/the-daily/electo‚Ä¶[0m‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mthat applies to some kinds of numbers some of the time, so it's interesting as a first diagnostic of fraud,‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mbut without an argument of why it applies to this particular kind of data, and without further investigation‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mof what might be causing the irregularity, it's not a smoking gun by any means.‚Å£

   [1mdodobirdlord[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mRevising our electoral system to change the incentives for political parties and politicians would be an‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mapproach. Winner-take-all on a state by state basis with single-party primaries produce candidates who are‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mfar from the median voter and then campaign to drum up support among their party base. Universal primary‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0msystems encourage candidates with broader appeal outside of their party to end up as the party nominee, who‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mthen have a much easier time running a general election campaign on appealing to opposition party voters‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mrather than being forced by the positions they took in their primary to campaign only to boost turnout among‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mtheir existing base.‚Å£
  [2m‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ[0m

  [1mthrowawayx7[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mSomething that should be addressed as soon as possible is reducing the capacity of foreign actors to influence
  [0mpolitics through organized trolling.
  [0m
  [0mThere has been a lot of gaslighting around this issue, but the fact is that the United States has been
  [0mprotected by two vast oceans for its entire history, but it opened a conduit into its heartland for foreign
  [0mmischief-makers through Facebook and Twitter. Whether it helped Trump or not in 2016 (frankly, I think it
  [0mprobably did but it's exhausting to debate this so I won't) it does represent a gaping hole in America's
  [0mdefenses.
  [0m
  [0mUntil this election, there seemed to be a clear pattern (in the English speaking world anyway) that allowed
  [0mone to reliably predict the winner of an election by seeing which side the trolls supported.
  [0m
  [0mThere are no First Amendment protections for Russian/Iranian/Macedonian click or troll farms. Detecting VPNs
  [0mand other attempts to conceal traffic is not an insurmountable technical challenge, yet it isn't done
  [0mconsistently.
  [0m
  [0mThe seductive "Arab Spring" approach to letting free speech run rampant on social media turned out to be a
  [0mmirage. Not only was the Arab Spring reversed in Egypt, based on my discussions with Egyptians, Facebook was
  [0mturned into a tool of repression after the counter-revolution took hold.
  [0m
  [0m(Yes, the irony of posting this from a throwaway account doesn't escape me, but there's a difference between
  [0mclearly anonymous speech, and speech that misrepresents its source).
  [2m‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ[0m

  [1mjustinzollars[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mBiden will be the First Democrat since Grover Cleveland to take office without a Democratic Senate. The House
  [0mmajority is smaller. So his mandate is effectively toast. Another interesting historical fact. America has
  [0mnever elected 4 consecutive 2 term presidents. If Trump would have been elected it would have been the first
  [0mtime in US history that this has happened. This election wasn't a blue wave by any means, Trump underperformed
  [0mHouse Republicans in many swing states implying this was more of a personal decision rather than political.
  [0m
  [0mWhat do I see changing? Not much:
  [0m
  [0m[2m  - foreign policy: policy changes with Syria and Iran[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - China: An end to tariffs[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - local changes: No more federal opposition to safe injection sites in San Francisco[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - federal taxes could still go up, the Senate has two liberal Republicans who could deliver tax increases to Joe[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - expanded federal regulations that do not require changes to the law[0m
  [0m
  [0mWhat will likely not happen:
  [0m
  [0m[2m  - PR and DC becoming states is no longer plausible[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - packing the Supreme Court is no longer plausible[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - a green new deal or expansions to entitlements are no longer plausible[0m
  [0m[2m[0m
  [0m[2m  - state bailouts are now in question, which could force major structural reforms[0m

   [1mcblconfederate[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe Doge wasn't selected randomly, but via a series of randomized election rounds in order to ensure that no‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcoordination was possible. Wiki has a fun description:‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mThirty members of the Great Council, chosen by lot, were reduced by lot to nine; the nine chose forty and[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mthe forty were reduced by lot to twelve, who chose twenty-five. The twenty-five were reduced by lot to[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mnine, and the nine elected forty-five. These forty-five were once more reduced by lot to eleven, and the[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3meleven finally chose the forty-one who elected the doge.[19] Election required at least twenty-five votes[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mout of forty-one, nine votes out of eleven or twelve, or seven votes out of nine electors.[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mAncient Athens appointed most offices by lot, they even had a democracy machine:‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[34men.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kleroterion[0m‚Å£
  [2m‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ[0m

  [1mjimnotgym[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mPlease permit me a ramble, there are too many points to fit in a hn box and I'm typing on a phone.
  [0m
  [0mI'm sure our stateside friends would be happy to acknowledge that US politics has a major effect on the whole
  [0mworld. I have had it pointed out to me before, however, that the USA can vote in whomever they please, and it
  [0mis none of our business.
  [0m
  [0mBut American companies sell us our books and films (understatement), take cuts of our credit card payments,
  [0mmake us coffee, organize our taxis. All of this seems to be with preferential tax treatment. All of these
  [0mthings could be done without the US, but the US is our partner in peace, so it is tolerated.
  [0m
  [0mAnd here is the rub, this works so long as the USA is a legitimate ally.
  [0m
  [0mAnd then came Trump, telling us that we don't spend enough on Nato (with US defence companies) and threatening
  [0mour peace. I believe this has lead to a situation where the US is seen less as a partner and more as a bully,
  [0ma colonial overlord demanding tribute. I think the next 20 years will see a shift in this kind of trade to the
  [0mEU and to the East.
  [0m
  [0mThe USA can be insular if it wants, but it can't do so and expect everything to be the same as it has been for
  [0mthe last 50 years. An insular US is a declining US. Your new President has a terrific amount of work to do to
  [0mundo this damage‚Ä¶

    [1mdodobirdlord[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mTrue, but on a deeper level NATO most of all serves US interests, and Joe Biden will grumble but happily‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcontinue to subsidize the defense of member nations.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThese days NATO is most clearly recognized as a list of countries that the USA as global military hegemon is‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mready to go to war to defend, and this is hugely beneficial to a country that wants to be a global military‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mhegemon. Wars are expensive and ideally you don‚Äôt want to fight any. The existence of an organization like‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mNATO means that (a) none of the member nations are going to fight each other, (b) none of the member nations‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mare going to try to rival the military hegemon, (c) nobody outside of the organization is going to start a‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mwar with any of the members. For a military hegemon whose main interest is ensuring global peace so that it‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcan continue to reap the rewards of a global economic system that it is also hegemon over, getting to mark‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0moff a large chunk of the developed world as ‚Äúno wars here‚Äù is well worth paying for. In a very, very loose‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0msense it‚Äôs sorta like an olden-days imperial power with tributaries, but the ‚Äútribute‚Äù is realized in the‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mform of the fact that the US government‚Äôs position as military and economic hegemon means that it can‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mmanufacture dollars for free and other countries will trade goods and services for them.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mOn top of that, concentrating the defense spending of the alliance within the US is good for the US economy‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mand critically important for maintaining the R&D efforts that the US military relies on to maintain a‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mtechnological edge over potential rivals outside of the alliance.‚Å£

  [1mbeloch[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mAs a Canadian, what stands out for me about the last two elections is that many Americans seem to desperately
  [0mwant a variety of political reforms, but neither party seems interested in providing them. Trump and Sanders
  [0mboth sold themselves as reform candidates in 2016, but only Trump wound up on the ticket.
  [0m
  [0mSanders might be the real deal, but he's not going to represent a major party until donation and campaign
  [0mspending limits (like we have in Canada) reduce corporate influence on U.S. politics. Sanders scares away the
  [0m"big money" that U.S. elections depend so heavily on.
  [0m
  [0mTrump has not proven to be a reform candidate in any sense of the word. As a political outsider with control
  [0mover both the house and senate for his first two years in office, he had the power to deliver meaningful
  [0mreforms, but didn't. Americans desiring reform [3mshould[0m have felt deeply betrayed by Trump's first term.
  [0m
  [0mThe democrats had a smoother primary in 2020, but decided on an utterly bland candidate. Biden is a return to
  [0mthe status-quo. I predicted that, after the last four years, a return to the status quo would appeal to many,
  [0mbut this election proves otherwise. This [3mshould[0m have been an [3measy[0m slam dunk for the Democrats to win, but it's
  [0mturned out to be a squeaker!
  [0m
  [0mIf the democrats ride the status quo for the next four years and both parties were to run the same candidates
  [0magain, I suspect Biden would lose. The Democrats need to pay attention to what Americans want.
  [0m
  [0mI would suggest that Biden's administration should, despite running on a thoroughly status-quo platform,
  [0m[3membrace[0m reform. Too many Americans mistrust their own political system, to the point that they're willing to
  [0mpicket polling stations because they think fraud is being committed. That must be fixed. Finding ways to
  [0mreduce the influence of money on politics (e.g. campaign spending limits) would be a good start. It will also
  [0mbe an easy sell to devolve and distribute some of the powers that have accumulated in the white house over the
  [0mlast several decades. If you're not comfortable with some of the powers Trump wielded during his time in
  [0moffice, then perhaps those powers shouldn't rest with the POTUS.
  [0m
  [0mBottom line, if the democrats try to pretend Trump [3mnever[0m happened and [3mcouldn't[0m happen again, they're in for
  [0munpleasant surprises.

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThe Electoral College votes on the first Monday after the 2nd Wednesday in December; so the 14th. What‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mhappens on 6 January is Congress ratifying the electoral votes.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mAnd it's the state legislatures that effectively elect their state's electors, which needs to be done before‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m14 December.‚Å£
  ‚Å£

  [1mEGreg[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mWhen I was growing up, Conservatives were the ones much more proud of US institutions, like the courts,
  [0muniversities, and even the free media, while Liberals and Leftists such as Chomsky were always criticizing
  [0mthese institutions, e.g. the media in the book Manufacturing Consent. (They criticized it as being too much a
  [0mmouthpiece of the government.)
  [0m
  [0mI find it interesting that four years of Trump's usual blame-shifting, together with his fan base, has
  [0mresulted in Trumpists blowing way past the Leftists in their distrust of all US institutions. This is far
  [0mbeyond the Tea party's displeasure with government spending. Sure, Republicans distrusted scientists before,
  [0mbut now Trump supporters distrust the following for partisan reasons:
  [0m
  [0mMedia
  [0m
  [0mPolls
  [0m
  [0mElection
  [0m
  [0mScientific establishment
  [0m
  [0mMedical establishment [[31m1[0m]
  [0m
  [0mUniversities
  [0m
  [0mCourts (so-called judges[[33m2[0m], Mexican heritage[[32m3[0m] etc.)
  [0m
  [0mFBI
  [0m
  [0mCIA
  [0m
  [0mIRS
  [0m
  [0mand much more.
  [0m
  [0mAre the institutions perfect? No. Is there fraud and corruption? Sure, but comparing to other countries
  [0mrelatively little, and probably less than in the past. But destroying Americans' trust in these institutions
  [0mcan be dangerous. I can understand dissidents doing it, but the President?
  [0m

  [0mwell off as to never having been too poor to afford health insurance but just above the cut off to get free
  [0mhealth insurance. Families with kids and high living costs, and then being forced to pay over $2000 as penalty
  [0mfor not affording healthcare, it broke many spirits.

  [0m$2000+ fine. Which he finally did.
  [0m

  [0mto pay that ACA "Individual Responsibility Mandate" while being poor in an expensive city.

  [1med25519FUUU[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mDecember 14th is the deadline to watch. That's the date at which the state must deliver the "Certificates of
  [0mAscertainment", signed by the governor. If they don't deliver by this date, the votes are forfeited.
  [0m
  [0mFrom this point to Dec 14th we're likely to see some interesting legal proceedings before the supreme court,
  [0msuch as whether or not ballots received without a postmark after election day can be legally counted (this
  [0mmight have impact in certain counties in Michigan and Pennsylvania).
  [0m
  [0m[34mcrsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/IF/IF11641[0m
  [2m‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ[0m

  [1mcgrealy[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mLeaving Trump aside for the moment, the last four years have shown up how fundamentally undemocratic the US
  [0mis.
  [0m
  [0mNo one ever expected Trump to get more votes than Biden. Even the Republicans were well aware of this. In
  [0mfact, 7 of the last 8 Presidential elections have ended with a Democrat getting more votes than a Republican.
  [0m
  [0mYet even with a 3.5 million vote lead, the perception was the election was on a knife edge.
  [0m
  [0mThis is ridiculous. The EC is an anachronmism and needs to be abolished. It made sense when it was
  [0mestablished, but it's clearly not working.
  [0m
  [0mSame for the Senate. [3m70% of people are represented by 30% of Senators[0m.
  [0m
  [0mYou desperately need to fix your broken electoral systems.
  [2m‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ[0m

  [1mgraycat[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mHere is a simplifying view: In the US there are some people, less than 1% of the voting population, who have a
  [0mlot of power and control of a lot of money and are looking to the political system to make more money.
  [0m
  [0mThis less than 1% do disagree among themselves, and that disagreement is the fundamental source of essentially
  [0mall the political fighting.
  [0m
  [0mFor the other 99+%, there isn't much to fight about.
  [0m
  [0mWhat the other 99+% want can be summarized in one word ‚Äî [3mmore[0m. For more detail, they want the two biggies,
  [0mpeace and prosperity. For more, they want "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness", financial and
  [0memotional security, love, home and family, good health, happy, successful children. There's not a lot to fight
  [0mabout there.
  [0m
  [0mSo, again, the fighting is from the less than 1% who want to use their money and power to get more money.
  [0m
  [0mOf course, way more than 1% of the voting population are highly concerned about politics, are fighting, but,
  [0msorry, guys, they are foot soldiers, pawns, for the less than 1%.
  [0m
  [0mAs an example, let's take one of the issues, say, health care. Glancing at history, US health care has come a
  [0mlong way since the lone country doctor with a one horse carriage. In terms of current US medicine, he was not
  [0mvery good. Point: Health care has changed a lot and is still changing, rapidly. So, what solution we come up
  [0mwith should accommodate such change.
  [0m
  [0mHealth care can be really expensive, and we need a solution for that. We need in some sense to [3mlevel out[0m the
  [0mcosts, make them predictable. Ways have been private medical insurance, health care membership organizations,
  [0mand government provided health care.
  [0m
  [0mSo, here are the main concerns: Private health insurance is too expensive for a major fraction of the
  [0mpopulation, so those people look to other options. Then for the other options, concerns are quality of care
  [0m(it might be too cheap and not very good ‚Äî loved ones could die), waiting times, and big tax increases. Point:
  [0mThese are all issues, but some examples can show that we should be able to do quite well on all the issues of
  [0mquality, waiting times, costs, etc., well enough that we should not have much to fight about.
  [0m
  [0mAnd there has been the issue of private insurance and "pre-existing" conditions. We can all agree that it
  [0mwould be nice for private insurance companies to ignore such data, conditions. And the richer US states did
  [0mhave laws forcing the insurance companies to so ignore. But maybe now the US is wealthy enough to so ignore
  [0mfor everyone. Hopefully. So, we can all agree or nearly so. Not much to fight about.
  [0m
  [0mSo, what is the cause of the the fighting? With some approaches and situations, for less than 1% of the voting
  [0mpopulation, there is or can be a lot of money involved, or a lot of power and then a lot of money.
  [0m
  [0mMy view is that we can go down the list of main political topics and conclude the same ‚Äî for 99+% of the
  [0mvoters, there's not much to fight about except some people, less than 1%, want to fight to make money, big
  [0mmoney.
  [0m
  [0mBut for various policies, operations, programs, etc., it really is possible just to make a mess, to create
  [0mwaste. At least the 99+% can be against the waste!
  [0m
  [0mE.g., for the [36m$trilions[0m W and Obama spent on Gulf War II, was that from (a) people who were in line to make
  [0mmoney from the effort or (b) just waste? I'd say, some of (a) but mostly (b). Point: Not all the issues are
  [0mabout the less than 1% seeking money and, instead, there can also be ordinary waste.
  [0m
  [0mBottom line: The 99% should throttle the less than 1%, settle differences, and get on with life.
  [2m‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ[0m

  [1mTheRealPomax[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mNo: he hasn't, and that's confusing to both "the world" as well as waaay too many Americans: the election
  [0misn't until mid December, when the electoral college casts its votes. You didn't vote for the president, you
  [0mvoted for what your state will try to vote for in December. Unfortunately, state representatives in the
  [0mpresidential election are not universally required to vote along the state election result, and while rare in
  [0mthe past, the current administration is clearly not above bribery and criminal endeavours to get what they
  [0mwant, when they need it.
  [0m
  [0m(Of course, if that's news to you, then you're probably not in the US right now)
  [0m
  [0mBiden is PROJECTED to win the White House, because that's how US elections work. It looks for all the world
  [0mthat he'll win, but he [3mmight not[0m depending on the electoral college: you don't win because the most people
  [0mvoted for you. That's not how elections work in the US.
  [0m
  [0mAnd before someone goes "what are the odds": this isn't 2016 when people still pretended to honour the system.
  [0mWe have 4 years of established corruption, exploits, and literal criminal behaviour to draw on. Until elected
  [0mby the electoral college, Biden [3mhas not won[0m. And remember that many states merely put a monetary fine on being
  [0ma faithless electors: it's not even illegal. $1000 to pick the guy who'll pay you back bigger, instead of who
  [0mthe state voted for? Scandalous! But also: entirely legal.

  [1mddingus[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mThe division and basically legal corruption are my concerns.
  [0m
  [0mOn a basic level, we are all people and all run the same basic way, and have the same basic needs.
  [0m
  [0mOne layer up, we are Americans. Those of us who travel, or who communicate outside the domestic US, see many
  [0mother nations and often a higher degree of solidarity as citizens.
  [0m
  [0mLooks like a priority problem to me.
  [0m
  [0mWe all need to earn enough to make it, or we all end up paying the costs associated with chronic homelessness,
  [0mfor example.
  [0m
  [0mWe all need to see the doctor too.
  [0m
  [0mEating good food, and the other human basics are not hard to understand.
  [0m
  [0mOften, I see "those other people" type arguments of various kinds too.
  [0m
  [0mLazy people. Different colored people. Weird people. Other people; namely, not people like us, or not in our
  [0mtribe, group, and‚Ä¶
  [0m
  [0mOrdinary people do not have very effective representation. Money talks. And it should, but that brings me back
  [0mto priorities again.
  [0m
  [0mNo judgement, no blame here. Just observations.
  [0m
  [0mI submit resolving these things to a more harmonious body politic is on us people. I am not convinced anyone,
  [0mor entity can just swoop in and improve things.
  [0m
  [0mThat is just where we are today.
  [0m
  [0mOne other observation:
  [0m
  [0mNations older than us have been where we are. Their peoples have had to do the work to get past it, and have
  [0mhad to do that multiple times.
  [0m
  [0mThis tells me we aren't experiencing anything fundementally new, in human terms.
  [0m
  [0mBut it is new to America. New in the sense of the USA being young enough, and the pace of change in the world
  [0mbeing rapid enough for the state of things to feel new, or like doom, or, or‚Ä¶
  [0m
  [0mGiven the burden of improving on our current state lies with us as people, citizens, I submit the following:
  [0m
  [0mWe all need to understand one another better. That starts by talking. Really talking and listening. This is
  [0mbest done sans judgement, and with deliberate intent to understand better.
  [0m
  [0mWe all are where we are in life, and we all have made choices, and relitigating the past does not appear to
  [0mhold answers for our future.
  [0m
  [0mThis is about what we do now. It is about our priorities as humans and Americans too.
  [0m
  [0mTake voting, for example.
  [0m
  [0mPeople had the following options:
  [0m
  [0mVote Major Party
  [0m
  [0mVote other
  [0m
  [0mNo vote.
  [0m
  [0mEveryone made their choice and had reasons, right?
  [0m
  [0mIf we apply the intent to seek understanding of one another and avoid judgement, that means having a talk
  [0mabout why people voted or no voted the way they did.
  [0m
  [0mPeople no voting, often did so because they did not want to consent to, or endorse, approve of what they see
  [0mas ineffective, corrupt governance. Or they did not connect a vote to a positive future for themselves and
  [0mtheirs.
  [0m
  [0mWhy is that? I think many, and include myself until recently, would rush to judge and blame.
  [0m
  [0mA vote for non major party X really is a vote for major party Y. Same for staying home.
  [0m
  [0mAfter talking some, the idea of candidates interviewing for a job comes up and poor or toxic representation
  [0mmeans not approving them for the job, and with that we see lazy, or stupid aren't really valid as reasons why.
  [0m
  [0mI will stop there, and urge you to think about how all of that is framed up as a duty, or burden and how
  [0mpeople may reject all of that in light of what they may see as an irrational election.
  [0m
  [0mSame goes for how people have voted or not before too. Those decisions are made, cannot be unmade and people
  [0mhad their reasons for making them.
  [0m
  [0mNotably, after some real discussion, the reality hits: we can't tell people to approve of potential leaders,
  [0mand we can't dictate what is best, nor their point of view.
  [0m
  [0mWe can talk to them and understand what they need to cast a vote. We can attract them to join a cause and all
  [0mthat too.
  [0m
  [0mSo why doesn't that happen more?
  [0m
  [0mI submit this is a big part of the priority and mutual understanding and consideration discussion we all need
  [0mto have.
  [0m
  [0mWithout that talk being a fundamental part of our body politic, we appear to be divided into factions, blocs
  [0mwho understand others, "those other people" increasingly poorly as pressure to avoid the worst continues to
  [0mrise.
  [0m
  [0mWith that discussion, it becomes much easier to see what we may consider an obvious, rational choice, say
  [0mlesser evil as an example, really is not so obvious, or may even be harmful, not a lesser evil, but perhaps
  [0mjust a different kind.
  [0m
  [0mNo matter how this all goes, at any given time our future is about the decisions we make together, the actions
  [0mwe take together, and the outcome we live with together.
  [0m
  [0mThe election is past us now, but please do consider it was about the votes people were about to cast, not the
  [0mones they may have cast in the past.
  [0m
  [0mTalking about all that is much easier and can be far more effective when people are not also fending off
  [0mnegative, and frankly until we understand one another better, uninformed personal judgements too.
  [0m
  [0mWe are divided to a harmful degree despite all of us having the same basic humanity.
  [0m
  [0mI urge you to talk, and I mean really talk with others very indifferent from you, who live differently than
  [0myou do and understand one another better.
  [0m
  [0mI do not know how we get our priorities in order as people otherwise. And without that, we rub the risk of our
  [0mfuture continuing to be an increasingly mixed bag for increasing numbers of us.
  [0m
  [0mFinally, consider this idea:
  [0m
  [0mWhen we make the discussion about what we oppose, it is not going to be about what we need, or want that is
  [0mgood.
  [0m
  [0mThink about trying to lead a team by only telling them what not to do. They will get somewhere, and it won't
  [0mbe anything anyone opposed either.
  [0m
  [0mWe all benefit from an explicit, public good. That means the basics are in order leaving people with free
  [0magency to get after better, or what they want.
  [0m
  [0mUnderstanding one another better will make that explicit, public good more clear.
  [0m
  [0mIt will improve our basic solidarity as people, reduce division.
  [0m
  [0mI submit one final idea:
  [0m
  [0mThere will not be a net public good we all benefit from and depend on, unless we make the discussion, body
  [0mpolitic, about it.
  [0m
  [0mAnd that is how I am playing it now, and have been for a while now.
  [0m
  [0mI want and need to be voting FOR good, not AGAINST bad, or evil.
  [0m
  [0mYou probably do too, and I encourage you to make more of the discussion about that explicit, public good and
  [0mdemand our leaders do the same things; namely, understand the people they need votes from better, and to apply
  [0mthat understanding to propose policy people can vote FOR, not just default to people voting AGAINST the very
  [0mworst.
  [2m‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ[0m

  [1mojnabieoot[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mWhile it‚Äôs true that the US government needs structural reform, the issue wasn‚Äôt anything the Constitution can
  [0mfix by nibbling around the edges. The issue is that the unified Republican elite, along with > 35% of the
  [0melectorate, is fundamentally lawless and anti-democratic, and will do anything it can to cheat its way into
  [0mpower. All three branches are implicated and have been for a while: Bush v Gore in 2000, the US Attorney
  [0mfirings, Shelby County in 2013, the refusal of the Senate to convict Trump in 2020, the disgusting
  [0manti-science politicization of coronavirus, and so on. The scale of Trump‚Äôs personal corruption is unique
  [0mamong Republican national figures, particularly in foreign policy. But the racist authoritarianism and
  [0mfundamental disrespect for elections is a defining creed of the party.
  [0m
  [0mOne of the more unpleasant truth about democracy is that it‚Äôs quite fragile. In any real sense, the US has
  [0monly been a democracy since 1965. When large segments of the population are ideologically opposed to
  [0mdemocratic governance - universal human rights, respecting fair elections, following the plain text of the
  [0mlaw, and so on - mechanisms by which democracy sustains itself begins to fail.
  [0m
  [0mOne possibility is to amend the constitution to change first-past-the-post voting in all local-to-federal
  [0melections, to let never-Trump types speak out without facing electoral suicide, and to divert
  [0mright-conservative attention away from a single ‚Äúleader‚Äù figure. And obviously the electoral college needs to
  [0mgo.
  [0m
  [0mBut the fact that more than 65 million people voted for Trump at all speaks to a great sickness and nihilism
  [0min American culture. Trump himself might be put out to pasture. But Trumpism existed before he got here, and
  [0mit isn‚Äôt going anywhere.

  [1mthrowaway201103[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mTo me what this election (as well as the 2016 election) illustrates, is what a poor set of choices we have
  [0mhad.
  [0m
  [0mIn no sane world should it have been difficult for the Democrats to defeat Donald Trump in 2016. He had no
  [0mhistory in political office, and he lost the popular vote to just about the worst candidate the Democrats
  [0mcould have put up. Had the Democrats put up [3manyone[0m who was less divisive than Hillary Clinton then we are not
  [0mwhere we are today.
  [0m
  [0mLikewise this time around, nobody I have talked to seriously voted for Joe Biden on his own merits. They voted
  [0mfor him because he's not Donald Trump. I have had people tell me they don't care if there is fraud and
  [0mcheating, it's worth it if Trump is defeated. Put up someone with more genuine appeal and you not only get the
  [0m"anyone but Trump" vote but you get enough undecided votes that there isn't any room for questioning the
  [0mresult.
  [0m
  [0mWe need better candidates who generate real support and appeal other than just not being their opponent. Not
  [0msure how to get there.

   [1msova[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mScore Voting is the solution ‚Äî give candidates a score from 0-99 and take the highest average score. Works‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mgreat to decide Olympian Gold/Silver/Bronze medalists. Plus, no vote is wasted, and bicameralism is‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mtranscended.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
    [1mnotSupplied[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mScore voting results in tactical voting where only the most extreme scores are given, instead of revealing‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mtheir "true preferences" on a grayscale. In fact, those who provide honest scores are disadvantaged, because‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthe deciding-power of their vote would be lower than those who purposely exaggerate their scores to the‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mextremes!‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mIt works in situations where there are few voters and their votes are all publicly visible.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
    [1myyyk[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mScore voting will increase polarization to levels unseen even in 2020 America, for no practical benefit over‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mapproval voting.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mScore's tactical logic leads to most voters giving the extreme scores to every candidate, and psychology‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mmeans all these voters will end up justifying it to themselves - leading to extreme polarization when the‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mlosing side is convinced the winner has no redeeming qualities whatsoever. The last presidential term showed‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mwhat happens than, now repeat that for [3mall[0m levels of government [3mall[0m the time.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mWorst of all, some very few people will actually give partial scores. Why is that bad? Well, what's the most‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcommon way to calculate scores [3mtoday[0m? There are various single-issue and ideological organizations which put‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mout scores measuring representatives. Just about all these organizations represent absolutist POVs‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mregarding their single issue or ideology (e.g. the NRA has a score for every representative). So to get a‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mhigh score, representatives are pushed to extremes.‚Å£
  ‚Å£
    [1melihu[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mYeah, that (or approval voting, or STAR) would be a good system in a primary.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mIn the general election, using plain score voting is a bit dangerous; if you consider a Trump vs Clinton‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mrace where all the Trump voters give him a ten out of ten, and most of the Clinton voters give her a six or‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mseven, then Trump wins by a bigger margin than he did in 2016. (STAR fixes this with an immediate runoff of‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthe top two after maximalizing everyone's vote.) But in a primary election, it might be good to get the‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcandidate with the most enthusiasm behind them.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mOne difficulty in implementing something like this for the Democratic primary is that it isn't very‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcompatible with the delegate system. Maybe that's not entirely a bad thing and delegates should be done away‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mwith, but sometimes it's good to have a group of people at the convention who can make decisions if‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0msomething unexpected happens to one of the candidates.‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mYou could have individual states adopt different voting systems for their primaries and just use them to‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mallocate delegates. For instance, instead of allocating delegates proportionally to anyone with more than‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m15% of the vote using first-past-the-post ballots like we do now, allocate delegates proportional to their‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mcandidate's total score, perhaps with some cut-off (like, no delegates awarded if your score average is less‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mthan 4 out of 10) or a rule that only the top N candidates are awarded delegates.‚Å£

   [1mfabianhjr[0m [2m9 months ago[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2millustrates, is what a poor set of choices we have had.[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mWe need better candidates who generate real support and appeal other than just not being their opponent.[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[2;3mNot sure how to get there.[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mThis is in great part due to First Past The Post voting method[[31m1[0m] employed. The US isn't interested in‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mdemocracy if they can't at least move from FPTP to something at least as good as Approval Voting. (Which is‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mone of the simplest alternatives)‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mSome criterions FPTP does no meet from Wikipedia[[31m1[0m][[33m2[0m]:‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m1. Mutual Majority Criterion: if a majority (more than 50%) of voters top-rank some k candidates, then one of‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mthose k candidates must win.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m2. Condorcet Winner Criterion: if a candidate would win a head-to-head competition against every other‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcandidate, then that candidate must win the overall election.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m3. Condorcet Loser Criterion: if a candidate would lose a head-to-head competition against every other‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcandidate, then that candidate must not win the overall election.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m4. Independence of Irrelevant Alternatives Criterion: the election outcome remains the same even if a‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcandidate who cannot win decides to run.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m5. Independence of Clones Alternatives Criterion: the election outcome remains the same even if an identical‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcandidate who is equally-preferred decides to run.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m6. No favorite betrayal: Can voters be sure that they do not need to rank any other candidate above their‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mfavorite in order to obtain a result they prefer?‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mAt least consider how 2, 4, and 6 affect alternatives like Howie Hawkins, Bernie Sanders, or Gloria la Riva‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mto name some examples. I find it hypocritical when US government officials criticize 1-party states when the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mUS is a 2-party state and as if that was a big qualitative difference.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[[31m1[0m]: [34mwww.wikiwand.com/en/First-past-the-post_voting#/Effe‚Ä¶[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[[33m2[0m]: [34mwww.wikiwand.com/en/Comparison_of_electoral_systems#‚Ä¶[0m‚Å£
  ‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mtemporary facility while you try to go through the legal process of evaluating their asylum claims or‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0munaccounted for. Most of the time, these two policies can be in harmony, but one day 20k people show up on‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0myour doorstep. Policy A says you don't turn them away, policy B says you don't let them loose into the‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mcountry. What do you do? And I'm not talking about what would be the long term ideal, if we have unlimited‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mtime and money. I mean what do you do about this problem /today/? You're probably going to scramble and set‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mup some temporary shelter while you get the policymakers to start figuring out a real solution, but you can't‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mjust call into existence beds, food, and furnishings.‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0m[2m ‚ñé[3m[2mand has lost track of 500 of them.[0m‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mterrible to some degree or another too. 2) The solution to any "interesting" problem - especially social‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mproblems - involves tradeoffs, conflicting objectives, pros and cons. If the solution really were trivial and‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0msimple, we wouldn't argue about it. The debate is because it's so complex, and with any really complex‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mproblem, you can have very reasonable and intelligent people draw different conclusions on how best to‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0mproceed.‚Å£

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0meverything is possible.‚Å£

  [0m[34mwww.newsweek.com/joe-biden-kamala-harris-got-big-soc‚Ä¶[0m
  [0m
  [0mSocial media has been devoid of Covid fear mongering since election night. For months we had daily stories
  [0mpumping out fear about Covid. For the last few days there has been nothing to talk about while we waited for
  [0mthe recount yet no USA-centric Covid horror stories have appeared.
  [0m

  [0mattempt to win elections".

   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mgovernment tends to be gridlocked except in time of national emergency (e.g., 9/11).‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0m‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mThis, I believe, is why the markets are reacting rather optimistically to the election results. Market‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mmakers clearly believe that a Biden presidency and a Republican Senate will get very little done, pass very‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mfew new laws, and spend a lot of time quarreling. This allows the economy to essentially run on auto-pilot,‚Å£
   [0m[33m‚ñé[0mwhich in a free market system is rather conducive to growth.‚Å£

  [1m11thEarlOfMar[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mSince the oil embargo of 73-74[[37m0[0m], which was caused by the 'Arab-Israeli War', securing the oil supply from
  [0mthe Middle East has been a top priority of the US government. The embargo highlighted how vulnerable the US
  [0mwas to the Middle East. Since then, 'Peace in the Middle East' has been a plum goal of successive US
  [0madministrations. President Carter was able to get a peace agreement between Israel and Egypt[[31m1[0m] which
  [0mcontributed to his ultimately winning a Nobel prize[[33m2[0m].
  [0m
  [0mSucceeding administrations failed to gain additional peace and instead leaned on regime change in an attempt
  [0mto oust unstable governments and seat US-friendly, stable regimes. This approach failed in principle: Regime
  [0mchange itself did not lead to stability. But instead, led to wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and ultimately, it
  [0mwas the protracted presence of US troops in those nations that provided stability. That stability was paid for
  [0mwith the lives of US soldiers put in harms way of militants from both within those nations and from outside
  [0mof them.
  [0m
  [0mUnder Obama, two threats emerged: ISIS and an emboldened Iran. ISIS went from a 'JV Team', to controlling an
  [0marea the size of Pennsylvania, spanning Iraq and Syria[[32m3[0m]. Iran was granted an agreement to suspend
  [0mweapons-grade nuclear research until 2031 [[34m4[0m]. Iran may or may not be complying with the agreement, but it was
  [0mknown that they were causing instability throughout the Middle East, funding ISIS, Hezbolah, and planning and
  [0mfunding ambush attacks on US troops throughout the region[[36m5[0m].
  [0m
  [0mThis was the situation in January 2017.
  [0m
  [0mReviewing what the current administration has done since taking office, the coordinated and deliberate steps,
  [0mand the results, have been astonishing, given the intractable and largely unsuccessful efforts to stabilize
  [0mthe region over the last 50 years:
  [0m
  [0ma. Established 'energy independence' by modifying US regulations on production of oil, natural gas and coal.
  [0mThe US became a net exporter of energy, reducing the leverage that the Middle East states have over the US[[35m6[0m].
  [0m
  [0mb. Moved the US Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem and recognize the Golan Heights as Sovereign Israel territory.
  [0mThis worked to gain trust from Israel, improving their willingness to participate in peace agreements. [[91m8[0m]
  [0m
  [0mc. Coordinated with Russia to eliminate ISIS. It was completely eradicated, including US Special Forces
  [0mkilling the leader and founder, Al-Baghdadi[[92m10[0m].
  [0m
  [0md. Withdrew from the Iran Nuclear accord, and renewed sanctions against Iran. The funds provided by the accord
  [0mlikely were used in part to fund their terror activities.
  [0m
  [0me. Killed General Soleimani, who was know to be the mastermind and source of funding for terrorism throughout
  [0mthe Middle East, directed not just at US, but other Arab States as well. [[97m7[0m] d. and e. illustrated to the Arab
  [0mStates that the US was willing to take decisive action to quell the regional threat that Iran posed.
  [0m
  [0mf. Withdrew troops from Syria, extricating the US from that war zone, after ISIS was defeated.
  [0m
  [0mg. Begin withdrawing troops from Iraq and Afghanistan. Most Arab countries want the US out so they can
  [0mself-govern again.
  [0m
  [0mh. With the above puzzle pieces in place, the administration rapidly concluded peace agreements between Israel
  [0mand three Arab states: United Arab Emirates, Bahrain [[93m9[0m] and later, Sudan. Other countries are said to be
  [0mjoining soon.
  [0m
  [0mi. Earned 2 Nobel peace prize nominations for the peace agreements (for 2021, winners will be announced next
  [0mSeptember).
  [0m
  [0mReviewing this timeline, and the magnitude of this achievement, it's hard to square the approach and its
  [0msuccess against the claims of ineptitude leveled.
  [0m
  [0m[[37m0[0m] [34mhistory.state.gov/milestones/1969-1976/oil-embargo[0m
  [0m
  [0m[[31m1[0m] [34mwww.history.com/news/jimmy-carter-camp-david-accords‚Ä¶[0m
  [0m
  [0m[[33m2[0m] [34mwww.nobelprize.org/prizes/peace/2002/carter/facts/[0m
  [0m
  [0m[[32m3[0m] [34mabcnews.go.com/International/isis-years-jv-team-inte‚Ä¶[0m
  [0m
  [0m[[34m4[0m] [34mwww.europarl.europa.eu/cmsdata/122460/full-text-of-t‚Ä¶[0m
  [0m
  [0m[[36m5[0m] [34mwww.state.gov/reports/country-reports-on-terrorism-2‚Ä¶[0m

  [0m[[35m6[0m] [34mtiny.cc/oilexport[0m

  [0m[[97m7[0m] [34mtiny.cc/defang[0m

  [1mpolitician[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mI am convinced that the main problem in the US is the structure of the Senate. It is preposterous to assert
  [0mthat the state of Rhode Island or the welfare state of Kentucky is as important to the security or economic
  [0mhealth of the nation as California or Texas.
  [0m
  [0mWe are a divided nation: people trying to make the best of their situation, and the Senate, a fantasyland
  [0mwhere we pretend that every state is equally relevant.
  [0m
  [0mThe "2 per state" rule worked back in 1776 because the states were roughly the same size, everyone was a
  [0mfarmer, and fertilizer had not yet been invented.
  [0m
  [0mToday, senators should be allocated based on the GDP of each state.
  [2m‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ‚ñÅ[0m

  [1m_hyn3[0m [2m9 months ago[0m
  [0mRegardless of media projections (and we know how accurate projections have been the last few years), it's
  [0msimply not true that Biden has [3mwon[0m.
  [0m
  [0mNo one has yet won. No one will have won the election until states certify their counts. It'd be nice if the
  [0mcounts, and recounts, were already completed. (Florida, of the "hanging chad" debacle, actually finished its
  [0mcount within hours in this election. Why did these less populous states move so quickly, and then slow down so
  [0mmuch, once it became apparent who was winning? Scroll down on this page:
  [0m[34mwww.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/11/03/us/elections/‚Ä¶[0m to see the timeline in the battleground states)
  [0m
  [0m[3mNo state[0m (out of all 50) has yet certified their count, and certainly no battleground states have certified
  [0mtheir counts. In fact, many of them have still not even finished counting the votes.
  [0m
  [0mTo assert otherwise, over a weekend when none of the recounts or court cases are resolved, is literally
  [0mspreading misinformation that many of the same media outlets are claiming to be stopping. Instead, they're
  [0mshaping the narrative and rushing to crown a victor so that it becomes a fait accompli.

  [0m[31m‚ñé[0minvolve a high likelihood estimation. Including ‚Äòwinning‚Äô a contract/deal, winning a race, etc. New‚Å£
  [0m[31m‚ñé[0minformation can affect outcomes.‚Å£
